Soft let me tread this sacred solemn ground,</br>Where Princes, Heroes, Statesmen silent dwell!</br>Whose breathing Statues Art had rang'd around,</br>To bid Remembrance' sorrowing bosom swell.
Pensive I muse, amid' th' immortal throng,</br>Whom Nature taught to wake the living lyre—</br>Warm'd with th' impression of their matchless song,</br>To Fancy's eye they breathe poetic fire.
This modest stone protects the sacred clay,</br>Of him whose genius pierc'd the bounds of earth,</br>Whose mind, creative, felt the heavenly ray,</br>And gave to worlds unknown poetic birth.
'Twas thine, O!  Milton, to describe the way,</br>As yet too noble for a mortal's tongue—</br>Tho' the mean Earth receiv'd thy sacred clay,</br>Thy soul enjoys th' Elysium that thou sung.

"The gorgeous Palace, and the cloud-cap't Tower"</br>Must SHAKESPEARE, yield to Time's resistless might,</br>But thou shalt live till by Almighty power,</br>The Globe itself shall sink in endless night.
While the slow stream of all-devouring Time</br>O'er Arts and Genius pours th' oblivious wave,</br>In Nature founded, view'd from ev'ry clime,</br>Th' immortal fabrick all its force shall brave.

Thy Works, O Handel!  chief in powerful Song!</br>To future times thy matchless worth shall bring;</br>Tho' mute the voice that charm'd the list'ning throng,</br>And cold the hand that struck the tremb'ling string.

No cheering sound is heard amidst the gloom,</br>To soothe thy shade, if wand'ring o'er this place,</br>Save when the midnight toll along the hallow'd dome</br>Proclaims to mortals Time's deceitful pace.
Long shall each Briton view with conscious pride</br>This sacred tomb inscrib'd with NEWTON'S name,</br>Shall hail him Chief, Philosopher, and Guide,</br>And spread thro' ages his immortal fame.
While on thy sacred form I gaze, ARGYLE!</br>Whose words persuasive rul'd the British state,</br>Whose powerful arm averted from our isle,</br>The danger threaten'd by impending fate,
Lost for a while in fancy's airy charm;</br>Thy marble bust seems yet with life replete,</br>And thus thou stood, for freedom boldly warm,</br>When truth resistless shook the British state.
The dauntless WOLF, revenging injur'd laws,</br>Who led triumphant Britons 'gainst the foe,</br>Seems yet to die in honour's glorious cause,</br>The weeping vet'ran shares his General's woe.
With rev'rence aw'd, I turn where CHATHAM'S pile,</br>Attracts with rapture every Patriot's eye,</br>Whose wisdom rais'd the fame of Britain's isle,</br>And fix'd his own, which never is to die.
May thy lov'd manes hover o'er thy son,</br>And pour the precept in his youthful ear,</br>Tell him the deeds for Britain thou hast done,</br>For which the column gen'rous Britons rear.
Bid him beware of faction's murmuring band,</br>Who sow dissension o'er the prosp'rous state,</br>Bid him not scorn a nation's high command,</br>The voice of Britons is supremely great.
The regal trophies scatter'd round, to tell</br>These are the sacred mansions of the great,</br>Their kingdoms dwindled to a narrow cell,</br>The blazon'd marble all the pride of state.

If History's stores recall not EDWARD'S worth,</br>Nor HENRY'S conquests warm thy patriot breast,</br>Tread not, whoe'er thou art, this sacred earth;</br>For here entomb'd these honour'd victors rest.
Thy suff'rings, MARY, need no sculptur'd stone</br>To raise the sigh by imitative art,</br>To paint thy charms, which once in Britain shone;</br>They live perpetual in each Briton's heart.
Born in an age, when beauty was a crime,</br>Thy form might e'en a tyrant's rage disarm;</br>But stern thy subjects as their rugged clime,</br>And cold each heart to every female charm.
While fame records ELIZA'S matchless name,</br>And pays the tribute due to Royal worth,</br>How learning foster'd first her foes o'ercame,</br>And arts and arms refulgent then shone forth.

Yet must she speak of one whose callous heart</br>Could hear unmov'd MARIA'S earnest prayer,</br>Could scorn the ties which friendship should impart,</br>And stab the wretch that, trembling, sought her care.</br>
